metadata.objective: Explore how consumers make decisions about plant-based milk alternatives, focusing on the attributes that matter most to them

turns.question:
Thanks so much for joining me today! I'm really interested in learning about your experiences with plant-based milk alternatives – things like oat milk, almond milk, soy milk, and so on.

To start off, can you walk me through the last time you were shopping for milk – whether dairy or plant-based – and tell me what was going through your mind as you were standing there looking at the options?
turns.response: Oh yeah, so I was actually at Whole Foods last week picking up groceries. I stood in front of the dairy case for probably like five minutes because there are just so many options now, you know? I was specifically looking at the oat milk section because that's what I've been into lately. I was comparing the Oatly barista blend with this other organic brand, and I had both cartons in my hands just flipping them over to read the ingredient lists. I'm really careful about added sugars and any weird stabilizers or gums they put in there. I ended up going with the one that had fewer ingredients and no added oils – I think it was like oats, water, and a little sea salt. Clean ingredients are really important to me because I'm trying to avoid inflammatory foods.

turns.question: Why does avoiding inflammatory foods matter to you?
turns.response: I've noticed I just feel better overall when I cut out things that cause inflammation. Like, I used to get really bloated and sluggish after meals, and once I started paying attention to what I was eating - cutting out a lot of dairy and processed stuff - that went away. Plus, I read a lot about how chronic inflammation is linked to so many health issues down the road, so it feels like I'm investing in my long-term wellness, you know?

turns.question: What does investing in your wellness give you in your daily life?
turns.response: I'd say it gives me consistent energy throughout the day, which is huge for me. Like, I don't get those afternoon crashes anymore since I've been more intentional about what I'm putting in my body. And honestly, it just makes me feel more in control – knowing I'm doing something good for my long-term health, reducing inflammation, supporting my gut health. It's kind of peace of mind, I guess.

turns.question: Why does having that peace of mind matter to you?
turns.response: I think it's because I'm really conscious about what I'm putting in my body on a daily basis. Like, oat milk is something I use in my coffee every morning and in smoothies, so it adds up over time, you know? If there are weird additives or questionable ingredients, that's just accumulating in my system. I want to feel good about my choices and know they're supporting my overall wellness, not working against it.

turns.question: What does feeling good about those daily choices do for you?
turns.response: It gives me peace of mind, honestly. Like, I'm not just going through the motions - I'm actually taking care of my body. When I know I'm putting good nutrients in, I feel more energized and just... clearer? It's about long-term wellness, not just what tastes good in the moment.

turns.question: Why does taking care of your body this way matter to you?
turns.response: It's really about feeling good in the long run, you know? I've noticed when I'm more intentional about what I put in my body - like choosing oat milk over regular dairy - I just have more energy throughout the day and don't get that sluggish feeling. Plus, I think about it as preventative care. The better I treat my body now, the less I'll have to deal with health issues down the road. It's an investment in my future self.

turns.question: What does investing in your future self mean to you?
turns.response: I think it means making choices now that'll pay off down the road, you know? Like, I'm not just thinking about how I feel today, but how my body's gonna be in 20 or 30 years. So that's why I care about what I'm putting into it - clean ingredients, avoiding inflammatory stuff, keeping my gut health in check. It's kind of like... preventative maintenance, I guess?

turns.question: What does taking care of yourself this way say about who you are?
turns.response: I think it shows I'm someone who takes responsibility for my own wellbeing, you know? Like, I'm not just going with whatever's convenient or heavily marketed. I actually care about what I'm putting in my body and how it affects me long-term. It's about being intentional with my choices and respecting my health enough to make informed decisions.

turns.question: Thank you for sharing your thoughts with me today. This has been very helpful.
turns.response: You're welcome! I'm glad I could help. It's nice to see companies getting feedback on products like oat milk - there's so much potential for healthier alternatives in the market.
